articles.headline: After a Season of Cutting, Stores Sweeten Discounts
articles.snippet: Analysts say consumers expecting even better deals after Christmas will not be disappointed, though they should expect more “bundling” from retailers.
articles.abstract: Analysts say consumers expecting even better deals after Christmas will not be disappointed, though they should expect more “bundling” from retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, reluctant consumers have forced retailers to lower their prices  and lower them again and again  before they even considered opening tight wallets and purses.

articles.headline: Burning Coal at Home Is Making a Comeback
articles.snippet: With the cost of heating oil and natural gas prone to spikes, some are deciding coal is worth the trouble.
articles.abstract: With the cost of heating oil and natural gas prone to spikes, some are deciding coal is worth the trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUGARLOAF, Pa.  Kyle Buck heaved open the door of a makeshift bin abutting his suburban ranch house. Staring at a two-ton pile of coal that was delivered by truck a few weeks ago, Mr. Buck worried aloud that it would not be enough to last the winter.
articles.byline: By Tom Zeller Jr. and Stefan Milkowski

articles.headline: No Furnaces but Heat Aplenty in ‘Passive Houses’
articles.snippet: Innovative homes pioneered in Germany are encased in such an airtight shell that barely any heat escapes.
articles.abstract: Innovative homes pioneered in Germany are encased in such an airtight shell that barely any heat escapes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARMSTADT, Germany — From the outside, there is nothing unusual about the stylish new gray and orange row houses in the Kranichstein District, with wreaths on the doors and Christmas lights twinkling through a freezing drizzle. But these houses are part of a revolution in building design: There are no drafts, no cold tile floors, no snuggling under blankets until the furnace kicks in. There is, in fact, no furnace.

articles.headline: Older Investors Should Examine the Risks in Bonds
articles.snippet: Older investors should check that their bond investments are what they thought they were -- and that they fit their tolerance for risk.
articles.abstract: Older investors should check that their bond investments are what they thought they were -- and that they fit their tolerance for risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: For people in or near retirement, bonds were supposed to provide a sense of security.

articles.headline: A Mortgage Paper Trail Often Leads to Nowhere
articles.snippet: With home prices in free fall and mortgage delinquencies mounting, pressure to modify troubled loans is ratcheting up.
articles.abstract: With home prices in free fall and mortgage delinquencies mounting, pressure to modify troubled loans is ratcheting up.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH home prices in free fall and mortgage delinquencies mounting, pressure to modify troubled loans is ratcheting up.

articles.headline: Foreclosures Don’t Spare the House of God
articles.snippet: The era of easy credit has begun taking its toll on even the most sacred of borrowers, religious institutions.
articles.abstract: The era of easy credit has begun taking its toll on even the most sacred of borrowers, religious institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of renting makeshift quarters, Seabreeze Church finally bought a permanent home in 2004 — a five-acre former tennis club in a beachside Southern California town.

articles.headline: Health Care That Puts a Computer on the Team
articles.snippet: There is broad agreement that moving patient records into the computer age is essential to improving care and curbing costs.
articles.abstract: There is broad agreement that moving patient records into the computer age is essential to improving care and curbing costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSHFIELD, Wis.  Joseph Calderaro, 67, is one of health care’s quiet success stories. Over the last four years, he has carefully managed his diabetes by lowering his blood sugar, blood pressure and cholesterol with diet, exercise and medication.

articles.headline: At This Casino, Only the Slots Light Up
articles.snippet: Opponents of smoking hope the Fernley Nugget, Nevada’s first casino built with a smoking ban in mind, succeeds.
articles.abstract: Opponents of smoking hope the Fernley Nugget, Nevada’s first casino built with a smoking ban in mind, succeeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERNLEY, Nev.  A Nevada casino without smoke might seem like the Strip without neon. But in this town off Interstate 80 a half-hour’s drive east of Reno, a new casino invites gamblers to breathe deeply, and not just to soothe nerves before a bet.

articles.headline: City of Immigrants Fills Jail Cells With Its Own
articles.snippet: In Central Falls, R.I., a mostly Latino city, few realized that a jail held hundreds of people caught in the nation’s crackdown on illegal immigration.
articles.abstract: In Central Falls, R.I., a mostly Latino city, few realized that a jail held hundreds of people caught in the nation’s crackdown on illegal immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.  Few in this threadbare little mill town gave much thought to the Donald W. Wyatt Detention Facility, the maximum-security jail beside the public ball fields at the edge of town. Even when it expanded and added barbed wire, Wyatt was just the backdrop for Little League games, its name stitched on the caps of the team it sponsored.

articles.headline: Italian Makers of Prosecco Seek Recognition
articles.snippet: Italian wineries want to protect their newly popular product’s name, as well as expand sales.
articles.abstract: Italian wineries want to protect their newly popular product’s name, as well as expand sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 1984, Fabio Zardetto, chief winemaker at his family-run vineyard in northern Italy, leapt at the chance to become one of the first bottlers to export prosecco, the sparkling wine, to the United States.

articles.headline: Satellite Radio Still Reaches for the Payday
articles.snippet: Deep debt, including Howard Stern’s $500 million contract, is causing Sirius XM Radio big worries despite growing revenue and subscriptions.
articles.abstract: Deep debt, including Howard Stern’s $500 million contract, is causing Sirius XM Radio big worries despite growing revenue and subscriptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DID you hear what Howard Stern said the other day? Neither did we. But we read about it on a blog.

articles.headline: Israelis Say Strikes Against Hamas Will Continue
articles.snippet: Israeli officials said the Gaza airstrikes, which killed more than 225 on Saturday and went on into the night, were the start of what could be days or even months of an effort against Hamas.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials said the Gaza airstrikes, which killed more than 225 on Saturday and went on into the night, were the start of what could be days or even months of an effort against Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  Waves of Israeli airstrikes destroyed Hamas security facilities in Gaza on Saturday in a crushing response to the group’s rocket fire, killing more than 225  the highest one-day toll in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in decades.
articles.byline: By Taghreed El-Khodary and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: White Farmers Confront Mugabe in a Legal Battle
articles.snippet: Farmers are challenging Zimbabwe’s land confiscation policy in a case brought to a tribunal of African judges.
articles.abstract: Farmers are challenging Zimbabwe’s land confiscation policy in a case brought to a tribunal of African judges.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEGUTU, Zimbabwe  Edna Madzongwe, president of the Senate and a powerful member of Zimbabwe’s ruling party, began showing up uninvited at the Etheredges’ farm here last year, at times still dressed up after a day in Parliament.

articles.headline: Saying Yes, WaMu Built Empire on Shaky Loans
articles.snippet: Washington Mutual stands out as a singularly brazen case of lax lending in a financial landscape littered with wreckage.
articles.abstract: Washington Mutual stands out as a singularly brazen case of lax lending in a financial landscape littered with wreckage.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We hope to do to this industry what Wal-Mart did to theirs, Starbucks did to theirs, Costco did to theirs and Lowe’s-Home Depot did to their industry. And I think if we’ve done our job, five years from now you’re not going to call us a bank.”
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Serving U.S. Parishes, Fathers Without Borders
articles.snippet: A diocese’s drive to import foreign priests to make up for a dearth of Americans is part of a trend reshaping the Roman Catholic experience in the U.S.
articles.abstract: A diocese’s drive to import foreign priests to make up for a dearth of Americans is part of a trend reshaping the Roman Catholic experience in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: OWENSBORO, Ky. — Sixteen of the Rev. Darrell Venters’s fellow priests are running themselves ragged here, each serving three parishes simultaneously. One priest admits he stood at an altar once and forgot exactly which church he was in.

articles.headline: Israeli Troops Mass Along Border; Arab Anger Rises
articles.snippet: With the death toll in Gaza rising to nearly 300, a furious reaction spread across the Arab world, raising fears of greater instability in the region.
articles.abstract: With the death toll in Gaza rising to nearly 300, a furious reaction spread across the Arab world, raising fears of greater instability in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  Israeli troops and tanks massed along the Gaza border and the government said it had called up reserves for a possible ground operation, as the death toll increased to nearly 300 after Israeli aircraft pounded Gaza for a second day on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Taghreed El-Khodary and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: A Page From an Old Playbook
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard has a tiny presence in the data warehousing business dominated by Teradata, I.B.M., Oracle and Microsoft, but is hoping to change the equation.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard has a tiny presence in the data warehousing business dominated by Teradata, I.B.M., Oracle and Microsoft, but is hoping to change the equation.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  Shortly after taking the helm of Hewlett-Packard in early 2005, Mark V. Hurd realized that, despite being one of the world’s leading technology suppliers, H.P. had an embarrassing and crippling technology problem.

articles.headline: Best and Worst Ads: A Year the News Eclipsed Commercial Breaks
articles.snippet: In 2008, the best-laid marketing plans of mice and men — or “Mad Men” with mice — proved no match for a historic presidential race and an enormous financial crisis.
articles.abstract: In 2008, the best-laid marketing plans of mice and men — or “Mad Men” with mice — proved no match for a historic presidential race and an enormous financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II described 1992 as “an annus horribilis” for her and the royal family. This annus may have not been that horribilis for Madison Avenue, but it came pretty close.

articles.headline: Online Piracy Menaces Pro Sports
articles.snippet: After years of focusing on the pirating of highlight clips and photos on the Web, the major sports leagues are finding that pirated feeds of live games are now common.
articles.abstract: After years of focusing on the pirating of highlight clips and photos on the Web, the major sports leagues are finding that pirated feeds of live games are now common.
articles.lead_paragraph: An important National Football League game on a recent Saturday night was dark on millions of television screens, but it lit up an untold number of laptops.

articles.headline: No Word on GMAC Vote as Deadline Expires
articles.snippet: The result of a bondholder vote to raise capital had still not been announced two days later.
articles.abstract: The result of a bondholder vote to raise capital had still not been announced two days later.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Two days after a crucial deadline passed, GMAC, the financing arm of General Motors, remained silent Sunday over whether bondholders had approved a plan that would help provide GMAC with federal bailout money.

articles.headline: Israel Reminds Foes That It Has Teeth
articles.snippet: Israel’s military operation in Gaza aims to expunge the ghost of its flawed 2006 war in Lebanon and re-establish its deterrence.
articles.abstract: Israel’s military operation in Gaza aims to expunge the ghost of its flawed 2006 war in Lebanon and re-establish its deterrence.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel’s military operation in Gaza is aimed primarily at forcing Hamas to end its rocket barrages and military buildup. But it has another goal as well: to expunge the ghost of its flawed 2006 war against Hezbollah in Lebanon and re-establish Israeli deterrence.

articles.headline: In America for Job, a Kenyan Priest Finds a Home
articles.snippet: Roman Catholic priests from abroad are being recruited to fill empty pulpits in parishes across America.
articles.abstract: Roman Catholic priests from abroad are being recruited to fill empty pulpits in parishes across America.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAK GROVE, Ky.  The Rev. Chrispin Oneko, hanging up his vestments after leading one of his first Sunday Masses at his new American parish, was feeling content until he discovered several small notes left by his parishioners.

articles.headline: TV News Winds Down Operations on Iraq War
articles.snippet: With a presidential election and its aftermath dominating the news, the three broadcast networks have quietly cut back war coverage.
articles.abstract: With a presidential election and its aftermath dominating the news, the three broadcast networks have quietly cut back war coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Quietly, as the United States presidential election and its aftermath have dominated the news, America’s three broadcast network news divisions have stopped sending full-time correspondents to Iraq.

articles.headline: Veterans of ’90s Bailout Hope for Profit in New One
articles.snippet: Top players in the savings and loan bailout of the 1990s are seeking to capitalize on the latest economic meltdown.
articles.abstract: Top players in the savings and loan bailout of the 1990s are seeking to capitalize on the latest economic meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A tight-knit group of former senior government officials who were central players in the savings and loan bailout of the 1990s are seeking to capitalize on the latest economic meltdown, enjoying a surge in new business in their work now as private lawyers, investors and lobbyists.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Skaters Jump In as Foreclosures Drain the Pool
articles.snippet: Amid the housing slump, skateboarders are finding a surplus of deserted pools in which to perfect their aerials.
articles.abstract: Amid the housing slump, skateboarders are finding a surplus of deserted pools in which to perfect their aerials.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, a 27-year-old skateboarder who goes by the name Josh Peacock peered into a swimming pool in Fresno, Calif., emptied by his own hands  and the foreclosure crisis  and flashed a smile as wide as a half-pipe.
articles.byline: By Jesse McKinley and Malia Wollan

articles.headline: No Early End Seen to ‘All-Out War’ on Hamas in Gaza
articles.snippet: Israel struck at the organization’s civic institutions, with no active diplomacy and protesters taking to the streets around the Arab world.
articles.abstract: Israel struck at the organization’s civic institutions, with no active diplomacy and protesters taking to the streets around the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel is engaged in an “all-out war with Hamas,” Defense Minister Ehud Barak told Parliament on Monday as his air force struck at the organization’s civic institutions — the Islamic University, Interior Ministry and presidential guesthouse. The death toll surpassed 350, more than 60 of them civilians, according to United Nations officials.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Taghreed El-Khodary
